title: 108_s2511
content: The Act may be cited as the "Chimayo Water Supply System and Espanola Filtration Facility Act of 2004". It includes definitions related to the Chimayo Water Supply System. The Secretary of the Interior will conduct a feasibility study for a water supply system in the Santa Cruz River Valley, specifically for the town of Chimayo, New Mexico. The study will explore options for connecting to regional or local water sources, including the Espanola Water Filtration Facility. The Secretary will conduct a study for a water supply system in Chimayo, New Mexico, considering various water sources and total lifecycle costs. The study must be completed within 3 years, with a 75 percent Federal cost share. The Secretary will coordinate a study for a water supply system in Chimayo, New Mexico, with a 75 percent Federal cost share. The study must be completed within 3 years, and a report on the feasibility study must be submitted to Congress within 1 year of completion or 4 years after the enactment of the Act. Coordination with relevant agencies is required for accessing necessary land and drilling exploratory wells. The Secretary will submit a report to Congress on the results of a feasibility study within 1 year of completion or 4 years after the Act's enactment. Emergency water supply development assistance may be provided for activities such as hauling water, installing purification technology, drilling wells, and constructing pump stations and pipelines. The Secretary may provide emergency water supply development assistance for activities such as drilling wells, installing pump stations, and constructing pipelines. The Federal share of the cost for these activities will be 75 percent. SEC. 104 authorizes appropriations for sections 102 and 103 for fiscal years 2005-2010. Funds under subsection (a)(1) cannot be used for water infrastructure construction. The Secretary will provide financial assistance for the construction of the Espanola water filtration facility in New Mexico, including various projects to meet future water demands in the region. The Espanola water filtration facility in New Mexico will include presedimentation basins, influent pump station, pretreatment facility, filtration facilities, finished water storage, booster pump station, sludge dewatering facilities, and potable water transmission lines. Financial assistance may be provided for the study, planning, design, and construction of a water delivery infrastructure for the Santa Clara and San Juan Pueblos. The Federal share of the total cost shall not exceed 25 percent. Federal sponsors will cover up to 25 percent of the total cost for the water delivery infrastructure development for the Santa Clara and San Juan Pueblos, but funds cannot be used for operation or maintenance. SEC. 203. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. $3,000,000 is authorized for the construction of the facility for fiscal years 2005 through 2009.
